chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The author's fortune. In the year 939 AD, during his sixtieth year and his thirtieth year as a monk, he traveled to Rome. He found me, caught up in worldly matters, and mercifully brought me to the monastery of Saint Peter in Ticino. There, under the brief custody of King Hugh, he entrusted me to Lord Hildebrannus for education in monastic disciplines.

Soon after, when we arrived in Rome, he deemed it fitting to take me, despite my unhappiness, as his companion. He had taken me from my parents as a canon and later returned me as a monk. During those times, while we traveled and talked, I boldly began to speak, setting aside any embarrassment. Feeling far from the monastic path, I dared to ask him about his life and upbringing. I urged him to kindly share his story with me.

As was his custom, he remained silent for a while. Then, wiping the redness from his face and sighing deeply, he began to tell me about his origins. His words were filled with tears and groans.
chunks.original_latin:
Auctoris fortuna. 4. Anno itaque Dominicae incarnationis nongentesimo
 tricesimo nono, et ejus aetatis sexagesimo,
in monastica religione tricesimo anno Romam veniens,
me miserum terrenis irretitum nexibus reperit,
miseransque suo rete piscatus est, atque coenobium
sancti Petri Ticini positus usque perduxit. Parvo ibi tempore ab Hugone rege detentus, praedicto
viro domno Hildebranno regularibus disciplinis
me tradidit educandum. Non post multo Romam
veniens, me infelicem dignatus est sibi socium
sumere; et quem canonicum parentibus abiens rapuit,
rediens postmodum monachum reduxit. Illis
praeterea diebus dum iter carperemus, simul loquelis
alternantibus, postposito pudore, et veluti monastico
procul posito tramite, audacter erupi in
vocem, atque sui ortus et habitus vitam conversationemve
non veritus sum ab eo diligenter inquirere,
pariterque ut mihi dignaretur exponere proclivius
 coepi rogare. Ille quippe, uti semper solitus erat,
paululum conticuit: deinde terso faciei rubore,
atque ab intimo corde suspiria trahens, suam mihi
originem coepit exponere: sed tamen illius verba
lacrymis et gemitibus erant plena.
